Literature Review: Photochemical upconversion has emerged as a promising field of research with significant implications for various applications, particularly in enhancing the efficiency of solar cells. This process, which involves the conversion of two lower-energy photons into a single higher-energy photon through sensitized triplet-triplet annihilation (TTA), has garnered considerable attention in recent years due to its potential to overcome the Shockley-Queisser limit in photovoltaic devices [1].The fundamental mechanism of photochemical upconversion relies on a series of energy transfer processes between a sensitizer and an annihilator molecule. Initially, the sensitizer absorbs a low-energy photon and undergoes intersystem crossing to its triplet state. This triplet energy is then transferred to the annihilator molecule through triplet-triplet energy transfer (TTET). When two triplet-excited annihilator molecules encounter each other, they can undergo TTA, resulting in the formation of one singlet-excited annihilator molecule and one ground-state molecule. The singlet-excited annihilator subsequently emits a higher-energy photon, completing the upconversion process [2].The efficiency of photochemical upconversion systems is heavily dependent on the properties of both the sensitizer and annihilator molecules. Ideal sensitizers should possess high absorption coefficients in the desired spectral range, long triplet state lifetimes, and appropriate triplet energy levels for efficient TTET to the annihilator. Platinum and palladium porphyrins have been widely used as sensitizers due to their favorable photophysical properties [3]. On the other hand, annihilators should have high fluorescence quantum yields, long triplet state lifetimes, and suitable energy levels for TTA. Polyacenes, such as anthracene and its derivatives, have been extensively studied as efficient annihilators [4].The kinetics of photochemical upconversion play a crucial role in determining the overall efficiency of the process. The rate of TTET from the sensitizer to the annihilator must be faster than the decay of the sensitizer's triplet state to ensure efficient energy transfer. Similarly, the rate of TTA between annihilator molecules should be competitive with the decay of their triplet states to maximize the upconversion yield [5]. These kinetic considerations have led to the development of various strategies to enhance upconversion efficiency, such as increasing the local concentration of annihilator molecules through molecular design or employing nanostructured materials to facilitate energy transfer processes [6].One of the fundamental limitations of photochemical upconversion efficiency is the spin statistical limit, which arises from the spin physics of the bi-excitonic interactions during TTA. According to spin statistics, only 1/9 of the encounter complexes formed between two triplet-excited annihilator molecules can result in a singlet-excited state capable of emitting the upconverted photon [7]. This limitation has prompted researchers to explore ways to overcome or circumvent the spin statistical limit, such as utilizing singlet fission materials or engineering the electronic structure of annihilator molecules to favor singlet formation [8].The magnetic field effect on delayed photoluminescence in photochemical upconversion systems has been a subject of intense investigation. External magnetic fields can influence the spin dynamics of the triplet pair states formed during TTA, leading to changes in the upconversion efficiency and emission characteristics. This phenomenon has been exploited to gain insights into the underlying mechanisms of TTA and to develop novel applications, such as magnetic field sensors based on upconversion luminescence [9].Recent advancements in the field have focused on exploring light-matter coupling phenomena to enhance photochemical upconversion. Strong coupling between the electronic states of the upconversion system and the electromagnetic modes of optical cavities or plasmonic nanostructures has been shown to modify the energy transfer processes and potentially overcome some of the inherent limitations of conventional upconversion systems. These approaches offer promising avenues for improving upconversion efficiencies and expanding the range of potential applications [10].In conclusion, photochemical upconversion through sensitized triplet-triplet annihilation represents a fascinating and rapidly evolving field of research with significant potential for various applications. As our understanding of the underlying physicochemical phenomena continues to grow, new strategies for enhancing upconversion efficiency and overcoming fundamental limitations are being developed. Future research directions may focus on designing novel sensitizer-annihilator pairs, exploring advanced nanostructured materials, and harnessing light-matter coupling effects to push the boundaries of photochemical upconversion performance.
